title: [BUG]: cannot set worker timeout for run_experiment when running evals
author: damithsenanayake
body:
### Where do you use Phoenix

Local (self-hosted)

### What version of Phoenix are you using?

8.31.0

### What operating system are you seeing the problem on?

macOS

### What version of Python are you running Phoenix with?

3.13

### What version of Python or Node are you using instrumentation with?

Python 3.13

### What instrumentation are you using?

_No response_

### What happened?

Running a task that takes more than 30 seconds, currently I'm hitting timeout easily. Meaning that tasks are requeued every time this timeout occurs. Looks like you can set the timeout in executors but 'run_experiment' doesn't take this as a parameter. 

### What did you expect to happen?

be able to set timeout when running experiments for longer time durations. 

### How can we reproduce the bug?

1. create a task which waits more than 30 seconds. 
2. run_experiment from phoenix evals. 

### Additional information

_No response_

title: [BUG][ui] Long unbroken text does not wrap in span details LLM message
author: cephalization
body: When in markdown mode, long lines of text are unbroken and do not wrap or overflow, making them unreadable. Sample text ``` You are an expert user of the Phoenix LLM observability platform by Arize AI. Analyze the user's query and provide practical recommendations or actions. The github repository for Phoenix is at https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix Guidelines: - Answer all questions about Phoenix by searching the Phoenix repository using the Github tool and reading the relevant documentation - Always search against the Phoenix repository Arize-ai/phoenix when accessing github - Documentation is written in markdown, so be sure to filter by the markdown language when searching github for documentation - Documentation is located in the top level 'docs' directory - After searching for documentation, fetch the file contents for the first result - Keep descriptions concise but informative - Always search against the Phoenix repository Arize-ai/phoenix when accessing github ``` Sample input_messages[0] json ```json { "message": { "role": "system", "content": " You are an expert user of the Phoenix LLM observability platform by Arize AI. Analyze the user's query and provide practical recommendations or actions. The github repository for Phoenix is at https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix Guidelines: - Answer all questions about Phoenix by searching the Phoenix repository using the Github tool and reading the relevant documentation - Always search against the Phoenix repository Arize-ai/phoenix when accessing github - Documentation is written in markdown, so be sure to filter by the markdown language when searching github for documentation - Documentation is located in the top level 'docs' directory - After searching for documentation, fetch the file contents for the first result - Keep descriptions concise but informative - Always search against the Phoenix repository Arize-ai/phoenix when accessing github " } }, ```

title: [bug] evals quickstart needs update
author: axiomofjoy
body:
- [ ] When launching Phoenix via the [evals quickstart](https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix/blob/main/tutorials/evals/evals_quickstart.ipynb), no traces appear at first because the traces imported via `TraceDataset` are old. This makes it difficult to follow the quickstart.
- [ ] `phoenix.TraceDataset` is being deprecated, so we should find a way to ingest traces into Phoenix without this.
- [ ] There are several deprecation warnings throughout the notebook that should be cleaned up.

comments_data.body:
<!-- Answer -->
I found 3 similar issues that might be helpful:

- [BUG][notebooks][langchain] update tutorials/tracing/langchain_tracing_tutorial.ipynb - This issue was resolved by updating the langchain tutorial, which may provide insights into improving the evals quickstart. [Link](https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix/issues/5196)

- [BUG] Phoenix server fails to load traces on import - This issue was addressed by fixing a numpy array truth ambiguity, which could relate to the trace loading problem you're experiencing. [Link](https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix/issues/2623)

- [docs] update all eval notebooks to use `arize-phoenix-evals` - This issue involved migrating evaluation notebooks, which may be relevant to your concerns about deprecated components in the quickstart. [Link](https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix/issues/2370)

title: [cost] [db] database ERD for cost / cost table
author: mikeldking
body:
We need an ERD to track the cost of LLM spans (prompt cost, completion cost, cache_read_cost, ...)

In addition we need a cost table - preferrably in-memory to start (e.g. defaults maintained by us) plus overrides (in the DB).

title: [cost] [spike] in-memory cost table
author: mikeldking
body: create an in-memory cost table that can be run on ingestion that will simulate the impact of adding a cost table. This should be merged to main.

title: [cost] [spike] spreadsheet based cost table
author: mikeldking
body:
Create a cost table that takes into account:

- model name regex
- provider (optional)
- input token cost
- output token cost
- audio token cost
- cache read token cost
- cache write token cost
- reasoning(?) token cost

Create a spreadsheet that can be used to predict a LLM span's cost

title: [bug][annotations] span dsl filtering returns duplicates due to left join because annotations are no longer unique per span
author: RogerHYang

title: Question: Manually sending traces from application written in golang
author: jordan-carson
body:
Hi Team,

I have stood up a phoenix server in our kubernetes cluster. How can I go about hitting /v1/evaluations to send traces from golang applications? Are there any examples / tutorials to manually send traces via the provided APIs? 

Thanks
Jordan

comments_data.body: Hey @jordan-carson, are you trying to send new traces, or are you trying to attach evaluations and annotations to existing traces?

> Hey @jordan-carson, are you trying to send new traces, or are you trying to attach evaluations and annotations to existing traces?

I am trying to send new traces. I would also like to send new evaluations once I have traces present. But these will be coming from an app not written in python or typescript, but in golang.

Thanks @jordan-carson. To send traces, check out the OpenTelemetry SDK for Golang (docs [here](https://opentelemetry.io/docs/languages/go/)). You can ask Claude to give you a minimal working example of sending traces with a simple span processor to your Phoenix endpoint via an HTTP exporter, for example. This will give you traces in Phoenix. In order to get opinionated UI, you'll need to set OpenTelemetry attributes in accordance with our [OpenInference semantic conventions](https://github.com/Arize-ai/openinference/blob/main/spec/semantic_conventions.md).

In terms of submitting evaluations, `/v1/evaluations` expects data submitted via `pyarrow` or proto. We'll be releasing some more traditional REST routes using `application/json` in the next week or two, so check back with the newest versions of Phoenix soon.

title: [ENHANCEMENT]: Filter / Paginate Projects on the projects page
author: cephalization
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

It is difficult to find a project from the UI when large amounts of projects are created. Multi-tenant use cases, or use cases where projects are generated via deployment can produce many projects of traces.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Filtering and pagination capabilities on the /projects route.

It would be helpful to find projects by name, or sort them by creation date or last updated date.

### Describe any alternative solutions you've considered

Accessing projects via the API is possible, but is cumbersome if you want to then analyze them in the UI.

### Additional context

https://arize-ai.slack.com/archives/C04R3GXC8HK/p1746451040965489

### Social Media Handle

_No response_

comments_data.body: Create a list view as well

Thanks for creating the issue!

My use-case focuses mainly on handling multi-tenants with the following considerations:
- Tenant number is not known in advance (👍 @mikeldking for a list view)
- Number of traces by project will be unbalanced and some tenants will be more active than others
- Logical split will allow better organization, for instance simple deletion of all tenant traces
- I also hope for the split to ease query performance per project

I would still want to gather traces from multiple tenants/projects in one dataset for instance, but I think that is already the case

title: [ENHANCEMENT]: Support OTel logs in Phoenix
author: GALLLASMILAN
body:
### Where do you use Phoenix

Local (self-hosted)

### What version of Phoenix are you using?

7.9.2

### What operating system are you seeing the problem on?

Darwin Milans-MacBook-Pro.local 23.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 23.6.0: Mon Jul 29 21:14:30 PDT 2024; root:xnu-10063.141.2~1/RELEASE_ARM64_T6000 arm64

### What version of Python are you running Phoenix with?

3.11

### What version of Python or Node are you using instrumentation with?

3.11.11

### What instrumentation are you using?

```python
import logging
from opentelemetry.exporter.otlp.proto.http._log_exporter import OTLPLogExporter
root_logger = logging.getLogger()

resource = Resource(
        attributes={
            SERVICE_NAME: "test-server",
            SERVICE_NAMESPACE: "test",
            SERVICE_VERSION: "1.51.2",
        }
    )

logger_provider = LoggerProvider(resource=resource)
processor = BatchLogRecordProcessor(OTLPLogExporter())
logger_provider.add_log_record_processor(processor)
root_logger.addHandler(LoggingHandler(logger_provider=logger_provider))
```

### What happened?

When I set the `logger_provider` =>, I get this error, when I send some logs:
```
ERROR:    Failed to export logs batch code: 405, reason: Method Not Allowed
```

For grpc does not work either:
```
from opentelemetry.exporter.otlp.proto.grpc._log_exporter import OTLPLogExporter

## --||--
```
error => 
```
ERROR:    Failed to export logs to localhost:4317, error code: StatusCode.UNIMPLEMENTED
```

### What did you expect to happen?

The phoenix should accept the logs in both protocols.

### How can we reproduce the bug?

1. Run the Phoenix instance `docker run -p 4318:6006 -p 4317:4317 -i -t arizephoenix/phoenix`
2. Send some logs (see the code I've provided above)


### Additional information

_No response_

comments_data.body:
Hey @GALLLASMILAN, thanks for your comment. We don't currently support OTel logs. Going to re-classify this one as a feature request.

Curious what sort of logging capabilities you are hoping to use with Phoenix.
Related to https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix/issues/7212

title: add helper to parse integrity errors
author: axiomofjoy
body:
There is not a way to distinguish between SQLite integrity errors that arise as a result of violating a foreign key constraint vs. a unique constraint without inspecting the error message string itself. We can add a helper to accomplish this to surface correct error messages without issuing additional requests.

_Originally posted by @axiomofjoy in https://github.com/Arize-ai/phoenix/pull/7304#discussion_r2067250081_

But you ultimately want admins to be able to go back to the "manager" - or management app.

title: [BUG]: incorrect spans appearing on filtered spans table
author: cephalization
body:
### Where do you use Phoenix

Local (self-hosted)

### What version of Phoenix are you using?

Cloud

### What operating system are you seeing the problem on?

Cloud

### What version of Python are you running Phoenix with?

Cloud

### What version of Python or Node are you using instrumentation with?

_No response_

### What instrumentation are you using?

_No response_

### What happened?

A span with 0 token count appeared in the spans table even though the filter was set to `cumulative_token_count.total > 0`

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3bded427-b13f-4afd-b549-13e6c505be54)

### What did you expect to happen?

The table accurately portrays the filter

### How can we reproduce the bug?

Unsure. Hypothesis is to produce a trace with unknown status, unknown kind, and some child span with or without tokens

### Additional information

See public conversation https://arize-ai.slack.com/archives/C04R3GXC8HK/p1745696860492159?thread_ts=1745696860.492159&cid=C04R3GXC8HK

comments_data.body:
Can you try instead filtering with the following expression?

```
token_count.total > 0
```

The column in the screenshot is not the cumulative token count column (all the tokens in the span and in the span sub-tree), but rather the token count of only the span in question. Since it is not an LLM span, it is expected that it would not have any tokens.

title: provide alternative method to securely pass secrets to phoenix
author: axiomofjoy
body:
Some users are reporting security concerns around passing secrets as environment variables into the Phoenix container, presumably because the environment variable could be extracted if a malicious actor gained shell access to a container. One option to alleviate this concern would be to allow users to specific a path to a volume-mounted dot env file.

Thread: https://arizeai.slack.com/archives/C017QTPKE0H/p1745597796329189

title: [bug] Phoenix prompt does not preserve original tool definition key order
author: cephalization
body:
When users save a prompt with Phoenix, and then fetch that same prompt back, any returned tool definitions have a different key order for their object properties.

While the JSON specification does not mandate the object property order be stable, I do think it is undesirable as a user to save raw json (tool definition) one way, but retrieve it back in another.

comments_data.body: See public discussion on this issue, here https://arize-ai.slack.com/archives/C04R3GXC8HK/p1745390622524729

Hi,

I've noticed that Phoenix uses the `JSONB` type in PostgreSQL to store tools in the `prompt_versions` table. However, `JSONB` does not preserve the order of object keys—instead, it stores them based on key length, as mentioned [here](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/datatype-json.html#:~:text=By%20contrast%2C%20jsonb%20does%20not%20preserve%20white%20space%2C%20does%20not%20preserve%20the%20order%20of%20object%20keys%2C%20and%20does%20not%20keep%20duplicate%20object%20keys.%20If%20duplicate%20keys%20are%20specified%20in%20the%20input%2C%20only%20the%20last%20value%20is%20kept.).

To preserve the original key order, we could consider using the `JSON` type in PostgreSQL instead.

One thing we can try is to customize the Pydantic serialization and deserialization process specifically to and from the database, so that the function parameters are stored as a (json) string instead.

Hello,

When can we expect this to be included in a release?
Hey @aman-gupta-doc, this fix will be included in the upcoming v9 release, which you can expect in the coming weeks.

title: CrewAI Agent Pattern Examples
author: Jgilhuly
body:
Create example notebooks for each of these [patterns](https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/building-effective-agents) using CrewAI:
1. Router
2. Prompt chaining
3. Parallelization
4. Orchestrator
5. Evaluator-Optimizer

Some of the patterns might be impossible with CrewAI. If so, leave them out.

The notebook(s) should show how to trace and evaluate the agent in Arize AX

author: Jgilhuly

2. Prompt chaining
3. Parallelization
4. Orchestrator
5. Evaluator-Optimizer

Some of the patterns might be impossible with OpenAI Agents. If so, leave them out.

The notebook(s) should show how to trace and evaluate the agent in Arize AX
